Description: Corroded copper alloy roughly circular stamp with a small ring handle in the center of the backside. The surface engraved with a decoration represents a human standing bearded figure of a deity, on top of floor line, wearing a kilt and a high headdress, cap or wig with long hair, looking rightwards while walking leftwards, and holding up two crocodiles by the tails, heads down, jaws opened, crested on their back. The image recalls the oriental pattern of the Master of the Animals, as well as, in an Egyptian context, the young Harpocrate.
Curator's comments: W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 77 § 76, pl. xli : "a curious seal with a man, bearded, with long hair, holding up two crocodiles by the tails".
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 80 § 80 , pl. xxxix, 1)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.45, p.66-67, p.182, pl.24)
